meaning_mnemonic: You have yourself a <kanji>void</kanji> of <kanji>weak</kanji>ness. This means you are <vocabulary>weak</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>feeble</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>abstain</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to abstain</vocabulary> as well!

控える is super versatile. It can mean <vocabulary>to refrain</vocabulary> from drinking, <vocabulary>to hold back</vocabulary>  comments, or <vocabulary>to stand by</vocabulary> (abstaining from taking action). In some contexts, it can even mean "to take a memo" because memo-taking is like putting information on standby!
Remember how 群れ is a <kanji>flock</kanji>? This is the verb version, and means <vocabulary>to flock</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to crowd</vocabulary> together with a bunch of other people.

You know 手洗い, right? This is like that, but way more polite sounding. The meaning is still the same though: <vocabulary>restroom</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>bathroom</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>toilet</vocabulary>.
You've seen how 岐阜 is "Gifu." Now make it a prefecture to make <vocabulary>Gifu prefecture</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>employment</kanji> (雇用) <kanji>someone</kanji> is someone who gives you employment, aka an <vocabulary>employer</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Tear</kanji> off a <kanji>one-sided</kanji> piece. It's only one part, not all the parts. It's a <vocabulary>fragment</vocabulary>.
Remember 御免? This is a polite way to say it. It means <vocabulary>sorry</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>I beg your pardon</vocabulary>.
福祉 is <kanji>welfare</kanji>, 社会 is <kanji>society</kanji>. So, a society's welfare is <vocabulary>social welfare</vocabulary>.

If you have <kanji>modesty</kanji> and are <kanji>humble</kanji>, then you are probably <vocabulary>humble</vocabulary> and have <vocabulary>humility</vocabulary> (and have <vocabulary>modesty</vocabulary> too, I guess).

A <kanji>fist</kanji> <kanji>gun</kanji> is a small fistish sized gun that has some punch (because, you know, fist!). The gun I'm describing is a <vocabulary>revolver</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>handgun</vocabulary>.

If you <kanji>dispatch</kanji> what you <kanji>think</kanji> to the other person, you're thinking about them, and you're being nice. You're showing <vocabulary>consideration</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>sympathy</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>compassion</vocabulary> for the other person.
原 is often tied to atomic things, as atoms are the origin of all things. If an atom <kanji>explode</kanji>s, you have yourself an <vocabulary>atomic bomb</vocabulary>.

If 充電 is a <kanji>recharge</kanji> then the verb version is going to be <vocabulary>to recharge</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to charge a battery</vocabulary>.

Remember how 甲斐 can mean "worth"? If worth is in your <kanji>nature</kanji>, you're probably a person of some <vocabulary>capability</vocabulary>. You're worth knowing and people appreciate your <vocabulary>dependability</vocabulary>.

甲斐性 means being dependable, responsible, or resourceful, especially in supporting others financially or emotionally. Traditionally it refers to a man's ability to provide for his family, so 甲斐性がない is often used to criticize someone for not making enough money.

You know that 生きる is "to live" and 甲斐 is "effect" or "worth." Something that has a good effect on your life and gives it worth is your <vocabulary>reason for living</vocabulary>. From your standpoint, it's <vocabulary>something worth living for</vocabulary>.

Keep in mind 生き甲斐 is mostly used as a noun, so you'll see it in phrases like 仕事が生き甲斐 (my job is my reason for living) or 生き甲斐が欲しい (I want something to live for).

Your <kanji>hand</kanji>'s <kanji>turtle shell</kanji> is the back of it (see you can make it shaped like a turtle shell if you try hard!). That's why this is the <vocabulary>back of one's hand</vocabulary>.

やり is from やる, meaning "to do," and 甲斐 means "effect" or "worth." So, if the thing you do has an effect and is worth something, then it is <vocabulary>worth doing</vocabulary>.

やり甲斐 is a noun, so it's often used in phrases like やり甲斐がある (to be worth doing) or やり甲斐を感じる (to feel worthwhile).
If 躍る is "to leap" or "to jump," then this noun version will be <vocabulary>jumping</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>leaping</vocabulary>.

The kanji means <kanji>inquire</kanji>, and the verb version means the same — <vocabulary>to inquire</vocabulary>. Depending on the context it can also mean <vocabulary>to hear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to visit</vocabulary>. 

伺う is a humble verb, so you can use with people of higher status to show your respect for them. For example, if you ask your professor a question or hear something from them, you can say 教授に伺う. If you visit them, you can say 教授のところに伺う. And in customer service, you'll often hear お伺いします, which is the polite way for a staff member to say they're ready to listen and assist.

If you do <kanji>penetrate</kanji>, sure, you can <vocabulary>to penetrate</vocabulary>. But, if you penetrate something you really get into it, like, you are going <vocabulary>to devote oneself</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Penetrate</kanji> the <kanji>night</kanji> and go on through to the morning. You were up <vocabulary>all night</vocabulary> and had a <vocabulary>sleepless night</vocabulary>, aka an <vocabulary>all nighter</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Penetrate</kanji> to the <kanji>bottom</kanji>. ALL the way to the bottom. Don't stop half way. This is <vocabulary>thoroughness</vocabulary>. This is <vocabulary>completeness</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>rapids</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji> originally meant a strait or channel, but these days it's mostly a place name: <vocabulary>Seto</vocabulary>. Some famous examples are Seto City (瀬戸市) in Aichi, known for its earthenware, and the Seto Inland Sea (瀬戸内海) between Honshu, Shikoku, and Kyūshū.

The <kanji>high</kanji> <kanji>rapids</kanji> are the <vocabulary>shallows</vocabulary>. How does that make sense?! I guess this means geographically high. So higher up the river, near the source, the water tends to be pretty shallow.

You'll see 高瀬 mostly in names, such as 高瀬川 (Takase River) or 高瀬ダム (Takase Dam).

A <kanji>withdrawal</kanji> is something you do to remove something from the <kanji>past</kanji>. It is a <vocabulary>withdrawal</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>removal</vocabulary> of what you did or submitted before.

If you do a <kanji>withdrawal</kanji> of something it's like you're <kanji>revolv</kanji>ing back to how things originally were. This is a <vocabulary>withdrawal</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>repeal</vocabulary>. It's <vocabulary>taking back</vocabulary> something you said previously.
A <kanji>withdrawal</kanji> of <kanji>soldier</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>withdrawal of troops</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Set aside</kanji> and <kanji>put</kanji> what you'll need to get the job done over there. These are the <vocabulary>measures</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>steps</vocabulary> we're taking to make sure things get done properly.

You <kanji>set aside</kanji> these <kanji>word</kanji>s specifically so you could get the <vocabulary>wording</vocabulary> right. Wording is important sometimes, like when you're trying to communicate something sensitive, or when you're writing a poem. Sometimes only certain words will do.

Note that 措辞 usually refers to the <vocabulary>phrasing</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>diction</vocabulary> of writing, not speech.

The kanji means <kanji>based on</kanji>, and the verb means <vocabulary>to be based on</vocabulary>. 

拠る implies a foundational or sometimes causal relationship. If X is based on Y, you could also say X is due to Y, or X depends on Y, right? That's why this can also mean <vocabulary>to be due to</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to depend on</vocabulary>. 

It's worth noting that this word is usually written in kana.

Something <kanji>based on</kanji> <kanji>points</kanji> has a ranking, meaning you'll know where your <vocabulary>position</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>location</vocabulary> is, compared to everyone else.
The <kanji>evidence</kanji> is <kanji>based on</kanji> something. What is it based on? This <vocabulary>physical evidence</vocabulary>. Ha ha! Guilty!

The <kanji>root</kanji> that this is <kanji>based on</kanji> is the <vocabulary>basis</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>grounds</vocabulary> for my argument. Look, it goes all the way down to the root problem!

祝儀 generally refers to monetary gifts for celebrations, such as congratulatory money for weddings. It can also include money given away when you make a hole-in-one in golf or win big on a gamble.

While 祝儀 can also refer to the celebration itself, this use is not as common.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wrap</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to wrap</vocabulary>. 

包む can be used in both literal and figurative ways, so it can be used for wrapping up gifts, enveloping someone in love, or even for fog or light enveloping an area. In cultural contexts, it also sometimes implies the act of giving a financial gift, since in Japan things are often wrapped nicely before being given — even stacks of bills.

Something you have to <kanji>wrap</kanji> up when you go into the <kanji>street</kanji> is your <vocabulary>kitchen knife</vocabulary>. Why would you wrap up your kitchen knife? Well, both to keep it from getting damaged and to keep it from accidentally cutting people, obviously.

Okay, the kanji don't really seem related to the meaning here. But that's because this word actually derives from the name of a skilled butcher character in ancient Chinese literature. The more you know!

The kanji means <kanji>attain</kanji> but the meaning of this verb is <vocabulary>to arrive at</vocabulary>. I suppose that's because if you attain something like enlightenment, you also arrive at that enlightenment as well. Thus, <vocabulary>to arrive at</vocabulary>.
If you have <kanji>attain</kanji>ed <kanji>summer</kanji>, that must mean you finished out with the previous season and are going into summer. This is the <vocabulary>summer solstice</vocabulary>.
If you are about to <kanji>attain</kanji> <kanji>winter</kanji>, then it's the <vocabulary>winter solstice</vocabulary>. Happy winter, everyone!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fake</kanji> and the verb vocab version is similar, it means <vocabulary>to lie</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cheat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to deceive</vocabulary>.

Some <kanji>fake</kanji> <kanji>attire</kanji> doesn't make you look fake, it makes you disappear. This fake attire is fake surroundings. So, if you're in a shrub, it's shrub attire. If you're in the darkness, it's dark attire. This is <vocabulary>camouflage</vocabulary>.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>amazing</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>amazing</vocabulary>! Or <vocabulary>terrible</vocabulary>. This word can be both good and bad, it really depends on the context, because what is amazing is usually also a little awful. You know?

Something really <kanji>terrible</kanji> causing mass <kanji>extinction</kanji> will be <vocabulary>extremely gruesome</vocabulary>. It will also probably be <vocabulary>extremely violent</vocabulary>, so don't look.
When things get <kanji>noisy</kanji> and <kanji>rowdy</kanji> there's a good chance things will end in a <vocabulary>fight</vocabulary>.

You can guess this is an adjective from the い at the end. The meaning for the kanji is <kanji>noisy</kanji>, so the adjective version is also <vocabulary>noisy</vocabulary>.

喧しい is a casual but emphatic way to say someone or something is too noisy. It's often used in Japanese comedy and variety shows, so depending on the situation there can be a playful vibe to it. You can even use it in a figurative way to describe someone who's being overly picky, fussy, or annoying about something particular (they're being "noisy" about insignificant details). Note that in everyday situations, you'll often just see this word written in kana as やかましい.
